/COMMIT_MSG.message: I find the above sentence completely confusing.  But I finally figured out what you're doing.  You're using older CentOS source for the package, and surgically replacing the actual source code tarball itself with a newer version from upstream.  I don't find this Frankensteinian approach acceptable.  Why are you doing this as opposed to just creating a spec file like we do for so many other non-CentOS source builds that we do?  This stuff is open source so you can copy and modify so long as you respect the license.  Help me to understand why you've come up with this strange approach.

If this is just temporary hackery until it's all replaced by a debian userspace anyway then I can probably live with it.  But the commit log had better make it crystal clear what is going on.  Any other thoughts/comments?

Hello all,

The resulting package's release does not contain the string 'el7':

 $ rpm -qip Packages/kexec-tools-2.0.21-1.tis.1.x86_64.rpm | head -n4

 Name        : kexec-tools
 Version     : 2.0.21
 Release     : 1.tis.1
 Architecture: x86_64

In either case, I guess that this patch needs to be redone. I would have reworked the patch if I had more time. My apologies.

Vefa

Well, the whole thing makes me throw up a bit in my mouth.  Does the resulting package produced look like it is a CentOS package eg. does it have an "el7" in its name?  If so, that's really false advertising, it could cause somebody to rip their hair out looking for that CentOS package upstream but it doesn't actually exist in nature.  You're really producing an stx specific version of the package, it is not a CentOS version with a few patches applied to it, nor is it a completely upstream version as you are packaging in other supporting files (taken from the CentOS version).  I'd probably copy out those supporting files, create a new spec file (edited from what CentOS was using), and put stx in the resulting package name so there is no ambiguity.  I'd also look hard at just using (or producing) the pure upstream version in its own package and providing the supporting files in a separate package.  Both packages could be produced by the one spec file ie. one build producing multiple packages.

But I would certainly like Mark A. to weigh in.  Maybe he's happy with your approach and/or maybe he feels it isn't worth spending more time on.

I agree that this approach leaves the 'el7' in the name and thus invalidates the 'law of least surprise'. Could we evaluate making a copy of the files instead, giving us the freedom to make the naming change. I do like avoiding making copies as it makes supporting things over the long term a pain, but this shouldn't change often. I thought we could patch metadata with the centos folder, could this approach be used to modify the package name?

Hello Jim,

Jiping updated the commit message so that it mentions the rationale behind the unusual approach taken by this commit. I unfortunately do not know if Debian includes 5.10 kernel compatibility patches for kexec-tools and makedumpfile. If it would be beneficial, I can find out though.

Is there anything else that could be done to improve this commit? Were you looking for comments from others as well? I personally do not have anything to add.

Thank you,

Vefa

Thanks for the feedback. I realize that I should have explained why this approach was taken, in the commit message. Sorry for missing that. Here was my rationale when preparing this patch with this approach:

kexec-tools is shipped with many supporting files that exist only in the SRPM package, and not in kexec-tools' source code tar archive. Please see the following directory listing in CentOS 7's RPM packaging repository to see what I mean: https://git.centos.org/rpms/kexec-tools/blob/c7/f/SOURCES

Perhaps I am incorrect, but creating a spec file from scratch would require cloning all of the files included in the aforementioned directory listing into the starlingx/integ repository to make things work. I opted against doing that due to the what I perceived as a maintenance overhead. Another reason was to keep this patch small.

I am all ears for any suggestions.
Maybe I misunderstood Jim's comment then. If the name is 'tis' and not 'el7' I think this is fine.

Hello Mark,

There is no misunderstanding on your end. I think Jim assumed that the resulting package would have the string 'el7' in its release field, so I wanted to mention that it currently has 'tis' and not 'el7'.

(This is an awkward situation for me, because I do not have time to work on this patch, and I cannot speak for Jiping regarding addressing Jim's comments.)

Thank you,

Vefa

If Mark is ok with the somewhat hacky nature of this approach, then I can live with it.  If it doesn't get much churn or will be replaced by something debian anyway, then it likely isn't worth bothering with a cleaner approach.
You should have a blurb in here about the change to that tox file.
Ack. Will do.
Done

centos-mirror-tools/config/centos/mock/r.message: Why are you adding these to the 'mock' layer?  This layer is reserved for the minimsl set of packages to create a mock build environment. These should be placed in the same layer as kexec-tools itself.

Hi, Scott
We find these comments in the file centos-mirror-tools/config/centos/flock/rpms_centos3rdparties.lst.  so we add these packages to this file.
# elfutils-default-yama-scope-0.176-2.el7.noarch.rpm provided by mock
# elfutils-devel-0.176-2.el7.x86_64.rpm provided by mock
# elfutils-libelf-0.176-2.el7.x86_64.rpm provided by mock
# elfutils-libelf-devel-0.176-2.el7.x86_64.rpm provided by mock
# elfutils-libs-0.176-2.el7.x86_64.rpm provided by mock

Yes, those non-static rpms ARE required by mock layer.  Static libraries are never required by the mock layer. i.e. mock layer is unique in that it is exclusively a runtime layer, not a build requirements layer.

It's ok for 'elfutils-devel' to go into mock, while elfutils-devel-static goes into 'flock'

So 

1) the gate is broken due to unrelated registry failures from updating zuul to new containers.  See https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul-jobs/+/813924/

2) https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/813922 fixes the centos-8 testing, which was broken and stopping us getting to centos-9-stream testing.

2) after testing in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/813912 we can not mount the XFS volume in the centos-9 .qcow2 on bionic, focal or centos-8.  I have filed https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2013894 to see if this image can use a more compatible format for it's main partition.

The other options are centos-minimal, which builds a chroot using RPM on the host, or perhaps the containerfile element, which gets an upstream container image, extracts it to a tar and then uses that as a chroot.  

It's not impossible I've missed something of course.  But at this point, I can't see how we can get this to work as-is.
was

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/814081

is the top of a stack that takes an audit of the current functional tests and updates things from building on bionic to building on bullseye.

I'm out of time, but my hope is that this change can stack ontop of that and will work to build there.  the other option seems to be build on centos 8-stream -- I would prefer to not introduce more platforms into the dib gate if we can avoid it, but it remains an option.

I understand your point, but you should also gauge it from the POV of the independent upstream project that we are putting in untestable paths; it will not build on any current OpenDev supported platform.  triple-o will not be dealing with the people complaining that the centos element with 9-stream doesn't actually work except for one specific exception.

From my investigation today, I think the only realistic thing to say is that the centos element can only build centos-9-stream images on a centos-9-stream host.  This is definitely a departure from the history of the element which has basically been buildable with any LTS distro as a host (the way it is used in other projects).  We should clearly document this constraint in the centos element, at least, and probably even put in a code check that fails on unsupported platforms to avoid confusion.

We might be able to test on fedora-34.  That is *very* unappealing; the long term implications of keeping that up-to-date is maintenance nobody wants to do.  Fedora 34's networking bring-up is also unstable in OpenDev as is.

I will try to prioritise looking at getting OpenDev centos-9-stream images via the containerfile element, similar to how we build fedora 34.  we could run this build testing on these nodes.  This may not be immediate, but if we have some preliminary evidence this path will work, it would certainly help the argument that it may not be testable now, but there is a path forward.

web/src/Misc.jsx.message:
I just came across this change and I like the idea to define those colours in a central place.
However, I have the feeling that those are too many different colours (or too many different shades per color). I didn't check it out in detail though and will try to do that in the next days.
Is there a reason why you went away from the PF4 CSS color constants? I was using them wherever possible to ensure that our colours harmonize with the PF4 design/components.

Regarding the variety of colours proposed in this patch:
I think we should stick to a small amount of expressive colours which you could clearly differentiate rather than a lot of different colours with a variety of shades for two reasons:
1. As Matthieu already mentioned those shades might be hard to distinguish depending on the display configuration and quality.
2. IMHO the amount of colours is distracting from the actual result and depending on the combination of the results next to each other it might even become hard to distinguish between e.g. green and blue results.
...There might be more reasons but those are the first two that came to my mind.

I would stick to the colours we have so far as they correspond very well to each other and also to the overall PF4 design (actually they are taken from other PF4 components and more or less reflect the main colours used for e.g. success and warning icons/buttons, progress bars and other parts). I assume that the PF4 developers took quite some time to come up with those colours and I find them a very good match. Those are

- green: --pf-global--success-color--100 (--pf-global--palette--green-500)
- red: --pf-global--danger-color--100 (--pf-global--palette--red-100)
- blue: --pf-global--info-color--100 (--pf-global--palette--blue-300)
- yellow: --pf-global--warning-color--100 (--pf-global--palette--gold-400)

We could then think about adding one different colous to e.g. highlight infrastructure errors, but I wouldn't add more colours. We should also keep in mind that non-voting builds are greyed out so we should avoid using anything "greyish" as colour for a build result.

In the current implementation we use the following "categories" (as I came up with the mapping I've also added a few notes):

SUCCESS -> green (The one-and-only "everything is fine" result)
FAILURE, RETRY_LIMIT -> red (To me those were the two "final" failure results which might not directly be related to infrastructure or something else).
SKIPPED -> blue
ABORTED, CANCELED, RETRY and all other "known" failures reasons -> yellow (This is kind of the "remaining results" category where I put in everything else). IMHO this category would be a good starting point if we want to revise some categories. 

I think it might be worth to revise some of the "categories" and move certain results into another category, but I wouldn't change too much about this.

You can just use the CSS variables and the color codes interchangeable, like here https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/812523/1/web/src/containers/build/Misc.jsx#b38

The same goes for any other CSS (color) variable, like var(--pf-global--palette--blue-50) or var(--pf-c-table--m-compact--cell--PaddingTop).

I wanted to give a unique color to each result, but it is true that that's a lot of dispersion, and besides, some colors are actually hard to distinguish depending on your display's configuration (and quality).

I think that at the very least, we should assign one color by type of result, so that it is clearer whose attention is required to address a potential problem. I've proposed this grouping below, and I'd appreciate feedback from other folks about its pertinence.

Also note that while I'm not using the CSS constants, the values *are* taken from the PF CSS palette, as is mentioned in the comments, see https://www.patternfly.org/v4/guidelines/colors/#color-palette - I'm sure it's possible to use the constants but I'm not very familiar with how to use styles, so any nudge in the right direction is welcome.

If we say that those results are not "error related", but due to normal events, I think it's a good idea to use the same color as for SKIPPED builds. However, I would stick to the current blue-300/info-100 colour as I find it much clearer to differentiate from the other colours and the cyan used here looks way to light.

I would group those together with either the failure results or the infra failure results. I don't think it's worth to spend a dedicated colour only to those.

I would also avoid to use both yellow and orange as they are quite hard to differentiate. Instead I would stick to the current yellow colour.

This is a category that could be worth spending a dedicated color to. Depending on how we split the other results, we might be able to re-use the current yellow color. Otherwise a purple variant might be a good match.

To me a POST_FAILURE is similar to a FAILURE result and might not be related to job configuration but could also be related to infrastructure or to the build itself (maybe an error in a script or something). I would use the same color as for FAILURE results or move it to the infrastructure/other failure category.
How often do we see those results in the UI? I don't think it's worth to highlight those. As those are all "failed" results I would also use infra/other failure color for them.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
As you said, single node deployment is not only a compute node, but also a network node.

"it may work" is not a justification.

> not only a compute node, but also a network node.

Which would make all nodes to be compute + network nodes in a multi-node environment if "agent_mode = dvr_snat" was set. And where snat components would land would depend on the l3 agent scheduler.

> "it may work" is not a justification.

I don't disagree about this bit but let me clarify why I am making the case for it.

From what I read in the docs before (and here [1] recently), it was not explicitly prohibited to turn every node in a deployment into a network + compute node. There were operational concerns about having snat namespaces scheduled to compute nodes but I think this is a compromise one has to make when trying to avoid dedicated network nodes.

As such, the documentation focused on the centralized SNAT aspect when making a distinction between network nodes and compute nodes. And, historically, network nodes were the ones that had connectivity to provider networks (DVR with direct egress via FIP namespaces blurred that difference).

Implementation-wise, DvrEdgeRouter builds on top of DvrLocalRouter (from early days of DVR [2]), and adds the SNAT-related functionality to it suggesting that network nodes (from the l3 agent perspective) have the compute node l3 agent feature-set + extra logic that may not be relevant to have on computes in all scenarios:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/19.0.0/neutron/agent/l3/dvr_edge_router.py#L28

There were changes landed over the years that suggested that running dvr_snat on compute nodes is not an unsupported configuration:

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/ee7660f593f0f997fff457021b3d5feb5c71906d#diff-aa990bf693c149a004522c0230588eda8160ec9075ef05c8d8906fe45fb099a4R360-R362
```
# Cover mixed dvr_snat and compute node, aka a dvr_snat node has both
# centralized and distributed floating IPs.        super(DvrEdgeRouter, self).process_floating_ip_nat_rules()
```

In the absence of an explicit doc entry, the usage of a single-node approach with dvr_snat in the gate tests [2], the implementation structure and prior fixes suggested that it was not unsupported.


[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/meetings/networking/2021/networking.2021-07-20-14.00.log.html#l-120
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/35654ec23ef9db6bda313ea300ab76c287a98ceb
[3] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/19.0.0/zuul.d/tempest-singlenode.yaml#L74-L79x
What environments?
To clarify: OVN is used for new deployments - the concern is mainly about the existing deployments.

Existing clouds deployed via OpenStack Charms with this option enabled:

https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-neutron-openvswitch/src/commit/2230c1e60f328e369e69afb6ece6a57b658a200c/config.yaml#L344-L363

There are a quite few users that rely on that to avoid having dedicated servers for network nodes. It has quite an impact on the cost in small clouds to have multiple network nodes dedicated to running a few network services.
I agree with this, but first we provide the support and then we change the docs.

I guess what we are contending is the blanket not supported stance here, when there is evidence that it has been in use for a long time and is present in many in the wild OpenStack deployments. 

There has been issues for sure, and we have pitched in and provided fixes for some of the issues our users have hit, and will continue to do so.

We have also bought into the move to OVN and are steering our user base in that direction, but we can't drop our existing user base on the floor until we get there.

> o/ folks
> 
> we discussed this in our tripleo-ci scrum yesterday.
> 
> Basically we don't have an objection to this (objection is a strong word, more like we are not going to try and convince you to use our tripleo-repos instead of this ;))
> 
> Yes there is some duplication in the module functionality. 
> 
> However tripleo-repos is used exclusively by our CI tooling (there has been discussion about using it downstream but we are a long way from that point still if we ever get there at all).
> 
> What is being proposed here is going to be used as part of the upgrades workflow in the product. 
> 
> So in a job that uses this new module added by jfrancoa, we'd actually have both in play. The tripleo-repos will be used to setup the repos for the job as usual and then this module from jfrancoa would be used during the tripleo deployment/upgrade workflow.
> 

Only from an upstream standpoint.  Things that go in tripleo-repos cannot (and should not) be used in the deployment code. It can be used as setup prior to, but is not available during the deployment/update/upgrade process itself.  tripleo-repos is independent and does not have a downstream component which limits our ability to consume within the deployment.  IMHO the ansible bits from tripleo-repos shouldn't be a thing because they cannot be reused within any other part of tripleo. It can only be used in development, CI or upstream contexts.

The reality here is that we're having to work around a poorly implement dnf feature which lacks tooling to automate so we're ending up with duplication of efforts.

> We'll be giving some updates on the tripleo-repos work at PTG so we can discuss some more next week

In reply to Marios's comment. This task was initially included because we were experiencing that many customers did not enable the right streams, ending up with a wrong podman version installed. So, the intention was to include a task that would be idempotent enough to not do anything if the user configured properly the streams and enable them if not done. Therefore, this duplication you are referencing does occur in the upgraded environments. The problem is that currently we use the dnf Ansible module for that, which does not only enable but install all the packages from the stream (and that's not really the behavior we expected. We wanted to let dnf decide which package requires to be updated during the dnf update *, not install them all). In the FFWD scenario this would be different, because we start from a clean state, so installing the whole group should not harm.

o/ folks

we discussed this in our tripleo-ci scrum yesterday.

Basically we don't have an objection to this (objection is a strong word, more like we are not going to try and convince you to use our tripleo-repos instead of this ;))

Yes there is some duplication in the module functionality. 

However tripleo-repos is used exclusively by our CI tooling (there has been discussion about using it downstream but we are a long way from that point still if we ever get there at all).

What is being proposed here is going to be used as part of the upgrades workflow in the product. 

So in a job that uses this new module added by jfrancoa, we'd actually have both in play. The tripleo-repos will be used to setup the repos for the job as usual and then this module from jfrancoa would be used during the tripleo deployment/upgrade workflow.

We'll be giving some updates on the tripleo-repos work at PTG so we can discuss some more next week

@Jose, as Alex mentioned tripleo-repos isn't used downstream, but rhos-bootstrap will be. I have no objection to include it here till rhos-bootstrap is packaged downstream and ready for usage by upgrades team.
Let's ask Alex if it's a viable option till then.

This release adds new policy targets for the volume-type API so that the create, update, and delete actions may be governed by different policy rules.  The new policy targets are:

For backward compatibility, the default value for each of the new policies is ``rule:volume_extension:types_manage``.  Thus, if you have defined a custom rule for ``volume_extension:types_manage``, it will still apply to each of the create, update, and delete actions.  You now have the option, however, of assigning specific rules to each of these actions.

Vefa, yes you are interpreting my comment correctly. From what we received from Intel NAPI is still in place in that a single interrupt will process the data which arrived to cause the interrupt, plus any new data that has arrived until all arriving data is exhausted or other stop conditions occur. In a standard kernel, where interrupt latency is less predictable, polling further improves NAPI as it can result in faster response times, can be prioritised... Having a fully preemptible kernel with the preempt_rt patchset applied should result in something similar to polling but with interrupts (with low latency). This will have to be benchmarked to validate the theory, though we have little as far as options on this.
Thank you for the detailed explanation, Mark.

Thank you for reviewing, Jim. I agree with you, but the time constraints and the fact that I am not familiar with the driver make it difficult for me to find a better solution.

Mark Asselstine had mentioned in a private e-mail to our Intel contact that preempt-rt kernel may hopefully be able to handle frequent interrupts more gracefully than a standard kernel. (Hopefully I understood Mark's e-mail correctly!) I will forward that e-mail to you. I hope that this will help. Thanks again.

  https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/kernel/+/805934/6/kernel-modules/intel-ice/files/0001-Fix-the-build-error-napi_busy_loop-not-defined.patch#7

specs/xena/approved/ncc-migration-ssh-au.message:
Rather than having a configuration option on ncc we could provide the nova-compute charm with an option to specify 'groups' it wishes to be a member off for which SSH keys will be shared - that would also allow some level of multiplicity as an individual nova-compute app could be a member of many groups (don't know whether than makes sense or not).

nova-compute would present this information to nova-cloud-controller over its relation - lack of presentation of groups would result in the current behaviour (no sharing).

I'm of a similar mind to James in this.  I feel that this should be a relation added to nova-compute to peer with other nova-compute applications ala 'juju relate nova-compute-kvm:migration-peer nova-compute-kvm-nextgen:migration-peer'.

I agree with Paul that it adds complexity, but if there were some way for those migration-peer connections to trigger relation update up to n-c-c that they wish to be part of the same "ssh key group", that'd allow for just using pure juju relation modeling rather than growing any additional options on charms.

Interesting idea.

> that would also allow some level of multiplicity as an individual nova-compute app could be a member of many groups (don't know whether than makes sense or not)

It totally makes sense re: belonging to many groups - that was the intent of the paragraph at line 71, to allow multiple group membership, albeit via the scheme currently described in this spec.

> we could provide the nova-compute charm with an option to specify 'groups' it wishes to be a member off for which SSH keys will be shared

That makes sense, but I feel like that may add some extra complexity to implementation which may not be necessary.  At the same time, user experience is obviously important and if we think that is a better UX, then that's fair.

In my opinion, the current proposed solution does have the advantage of simplicity of implementation.  With the extra config option, NCC would have all the information it needs to power this without any changes to nova-compute and without any additional examination of relation data.  It'd just look at the proposed config option for grouped apps, then serve the keys/known_hosts from all apps in the group rather than just the immediate remote app.  Data is already stored on disk by remote app name, so this would be very simple to do with a minimum of code.

If we introduce group names driven from the nova-computes, it seems like we'd need to patch two charms (although nova-compute's change would be pretty trivial), and we'd have to resolve from group names to member applications, either by relation data walking at the time of sharing the data, or by tracking the group-to-app mapping in some other way.  That's not a ton of work, but it does seem like unnecessary complexity - unless we strongly prefer the UX of having this controlled via nova-compute instead.

+1 on James' suggestion. It is slightly different than the original version in the sense that the config lives on the nova-compute charm but it is verified and applied by the ncc charm. It does not add too many hook executions on top of the existing ones.
I'm +1 for Paul's simpler solution as it doesn't require any changes to the nova-computes and it keeps the 'sharing' configuration in a single place, rather than spreading it over multiple apps.

Very interesting.

All of these seem like valid approaches, but at the end of the day, I probably wouldn't be maintaining this feature in the long-term.  That, and I see clearly there's enough variety of opinions that I'm not going to push for my initial version unless it can stand on its own merits somehow.

To those of you who are generally long-term on OpenStack charm development - perhaps one of these approaches can be selected and we can settle on that as the approach?
Alternatively, maybe I should just use bug/1468871?

I think we need a work item here to look at the performance of setting so many ssh keys across the relation.  The '*' option essentially shares all keys on all apps to all relations, and inspection of the code indicates that there's two subprocess calls for each relation_set call (one to see if the set-relation allows a file).  Thus some kind of chunking should be used to reduce the number of calls.

I'd also like to see charm-upgrade to be explored here to ensure that there are no 'gotchas' in the implementation.

> Will this formatting always work?

Do you have a specific issue in mind?

From dnf.conf(5): The configuration file has INI format consisting of section declaration and name=value options below each on separate line.

> Are all options in the [main] section?

As quoted above, you could technically define repository sections inside dnf.conf, but we always use yum.repos.d files for this. Our dnf role actually hardcodes the main section:

https://opendev.org/openstack/kayobe/src/branch/master/ansible/roles/dnf/tasks/main.yml#L5
 
> Does the file always exist? If not it would end up with no [main] section heading.

This file comes as part of dnf-data which is a dependency of dnf, which is a protected package. The default content (in CentOS Stream 8) is:

[main]
gpgcheck=1
installonly_limit=3
clean_requirements_on_remove=True
best=True
skip_if_unavailable=False

> Will substring matches cause problems for the grep?

That could be a problem, I can make it smarter.

An alternative would be to use --setopt option on the CLI.
I submitted an new patch using --setopt. No more editing of dnf.conf.

specs/prometheus.rst.message: it would be great to start this out right by generating this from inventory, rather than being a separate file you need to update and often forget about (similar to the way sslcheck now works, automatically adding hosts that use letsencrypt)

I doubt writing grafyaml will be much fun for this.  https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/system-config/latest/grafana.html#local-development describes how we should be able to do this in a more interactive manner; may need updating to cover the prometheus stats instead of graphite
It sounds like this spec is about replacing Cacti. Could the snmp and the other exporters be defined as independent follow-up?

SNMP is the key bit that Cacti provides currently. This is why it is a core component of this change. I also suspect that integrating exporters for things like gitea and gerrit will be more straightforward than SNMP and we can add them in without much fuss once we have gotten this SNMP stuff working.

I would suggest to look at this variant first or at least in parallel, possibly limited to those hosts on which we are running docker already, so that starting a node-exporter container would be easy.

I haven't much experience either, but this would likely allow us to make use of a predefined set of metrics that are being collected and also a dashboard that presents all these metrics in a useful way, without any additional configuration being needed.
If there are no initial assignees, the spec should be proposed into the help wanted rather than approved section.

We should pick one or the other.  Supporting both will produce values we can't compare between hosts and increase our maintenance cost.

If we want to defer that decision for now, that's fine (though I think it could be made now with a little more research).  But at some point we should make an A/B decision and push through updates quickly.  An extended straddle would be very undesirable.

In the meeting we talked about running this in a container; but does a container have the right overview of the system to produce the stats?  it seems like the type of thing you want running on a base system.
Are these binaries going to match the security/support lifetimes of our distros?

I think the idea would be we could do a concerted update of the binary version we choose to a new version to address security updates. Then even if metric names change (though that seems to not be a thing since the stable 1.0 release) we change globally and can address them in the graphs easily.

https://prometheus.io/docs/operating/security/#build-process this page as a whole has interesting info but this specific section points out we can build our own if absolutely necessary. Probably best to avoid that.

Since this binary is a golang binary we also need to consider its runtime needs. Googling around the main consideration there seems to be for what version of glibc gets statically linked in and whether or not it supports older kernels you may be running. Based on https://ops.tips/notes/glibc-golang-learnings/ there is some risk that node-exporter could be built with a very new glibc and then not run on older machines. If this happens we would want to build it ourselves against an older glibc.

There is definitely some risk here, but it seems minimal as long as we are ok with the fallback of building it ourselves: https://github.com/prometheus/node_exporter/blob/master/README.md#development-building-and-running

Ok, after a talk with podman guys, I think TimeoutStopSec should be larger than ExecStop + ExecStopPost timeouts. And TBH ExecStopPost looks like redundant here if we have TimeoutStopSec.

<sshnaidm> vrothberg, sorry, I'm trying to picture the case if container is stuck, if execstop failed to stop it in its timeout. Will execpost conflict with TimeoutStopSec here?
<vrothberg> sshnaidm: there is a theoretical conflict/race. That is why Podman adds 60 seconds to the specified time out.  That should give the container and Podman largely enough time to clean up before systemd would hypothetically nuke everything.
<vrothberg> sshnaidm: the custom TimeoutStopSec is intended to prevent a race/conflict.
<vrothberg> I think by default it's also 10 seconds, and hence the same as Podman, so we needed to bump it up.
<sshnaidm> vrothberg, ack, so if I got it right - if container is stuck, execstop is trying to stop it, if can't - exec-post-stop is trying to rm -f it, and then after a timeout systemd is trying to erase everything there. Is it correct?
<vrothberg> sshnaidm: if `podman stop` hits the timeout, the container will get killed. Then `podman rm -f` will remove it and clean up. Systemd will only nuke if the previous steps take more than $timeout + 60 secs

Even if they are only shared between the ProjectMember and ProjectReader classes, I'm an advocate for putting shared utilities in a base class that isn't specific to test cases themselves.

I find that keeping utilities in a separate object from the tests makes the utilities easier to share in the future and promotes better organization. Otherwise, if for some reason we have another set of tests cases to add that would benefit from using assert*Object, they would need to either inherit extra test cases or we'd need to move them to a common place anyway.

ack.

I will update the same for remaining tests

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/node.message: Is there a need for the if/else given that you already check if 'networks' is in the spec on line 69?

There might be Subnets that does not use a Trunk. Shouldn't we always only look for the ones with Trunks in order to create the Ports pool and handle Network Policy?
There is a Trunks field defined on Ports and MachineSpec https://github.com/openshift/cluster-api-provider-openstack/blob/release-4.9/pkg/apis/openstackproviderconfig/v1alpha1/types.go
Makes sense, we might want to check if openStackMachine.Spec.Trunk is set to True. If so - use first port we find. If not - use first port with trunk that we find.
Maybe we would want this not to explode if `networks` is just empty list. I know, it was like this previously. ;)
